newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan to sell state telecom shares in '98 - papers.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to sell state telecom shares in '98 - papers.

text.p: Taiwan would sell between 10 and 30 percent of shares in state-owned Chunghwa Telecom Co at the end of 1998 as part of its privatisation plan, several Taiwan newspapers reported on Sunday.
Under a proposed plan, Chunghwa would also consider selling 20 percent of stakes to overseas investors.
Chunghwa, capitalised at T$96 billion, was in the process of revaluating its assets, the Commercial Times newspaper said.

Before Chunghwa became a company in July 1996, it was a part of Taiwan government's Directorate General of Telecommunications which had monopolised the island's telecommunications business for 48 years.
Under reform laws enacted in January 1996, Taiwan liberalised its telecommunication market.
Foreign interests may own up to 20 percent of Taiwan firms offering common-carrier services, a ratio designed by parliament to ensure local control of what is considered a strategic resource.
Common-carrier services are the main telephone and data lines in Taiwan's telecom network, including mobile telephony and retail telephone services.
Since January 1996, foreigners have been free to own to operate Internet services, airline reservation systems and other value-added services that piggy-back common carrier networks.
